Award.AwardTitle: CRII: NeTS: A Proactive Perspective on Preventing Network Inference: Shifting from Optimized to Dynamic Wireless Network Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will design strategies to thwart malicious efforts targeting the inference of information from wireless networks. New proactive anti-inference strategies will be developed and tested to make networks more dynamic and less inference-susceptible. The project involves the training of undergraduate and graduate students in network inference/anti-inference theoretical and experimental activities, and is expected to significantly impact the security design of mission-critical wireless networks.

Network inference is an effective way to infer the information of network statistics and properties from network measurements. Network inference has enabled a wide range of applications, such as network surveillance, management and diagnosis; however, in certain circumstances, such as wireless networks for military applications, it is important to mask this information to prevent the use of inference for malicious intent. To date, strategies for anti-inference in wireless networks have been overlooked and under-explored. The central goal of this effort is to address the current gap in understanding by exploring the fundamental aspects of proactive strategies that will enable a wide range of anti-inference applications. Specific objectives are to (1) develop a theoretical framework to analyze the behaviors of proactive strategies that enhance network dynamics to achieve anti-inference; (2) reveal the fundamental relationship between the impacts and costs of network dynamics based anti-inference strategies; and (3) implement efficient anti-inference design for network applications. To accomplish these objectives, both deception traffic and routing changing strategies will be utilized to induce higher dynamics in the network to make inference inaccurate. In addition, the cost-benefit impact of these strategies will be examined by shifting from optimized to dynamic network design.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Network inference is an effective method to infer underlying network information (e.g., network connectivity and traffic information). The project aims to investigate how to use proactive network designs to prevent undesirable or malicious network inference from being effective from the security perspective. The key research to build security is to exploit network dynamics coming from two major proactive strategies: 1) deception traffic, in which network nodes transmit redundant traffic to add more noise to the network inference process, 2) routing changing, in which network nodes keep changing their data routing paths unpredictable to the network inference process, therefore causing the confusion in network inference.

The project has used theoretical models and frameworks as well as comprehensive evaluations to measure both the security benefits and the associated costs of the deception traffic and routing changing strategies. It is found in the project that the deception traffic strategy only causes a limited performance degradation compared with the routing change strategy. Transmitting deception traffic independently and randomly at network nodes is only slightly worse than the best coordinated strategy to transmit deception traffic among all nodes, which may incur higher complexity in a large-scale network. The routing changing strategy is found generally better than deception traffic to prevent network inference with higher security benefits and approximately similar costs. Moreover, combining routing changing and deception traffic strategies cannot significantly boost the impact of disrupting network inference. Rather, the security benefit is dominated by whatever individual strategy that leads to more inference error in the network inference process than the other. This means that the combined strategy is not always desirable because of its slight security improvement at the double cost. As a result, routing changing is generally appropriate as a proactive network design model for network security. The project also shows that routing changing can be built upon existing network routing protocols and compares in detail the benefits and costs of building a practical routing changing design on these protocols to achieve the security benefits.  

It is also found in the project that proactive network behavior can be used as am attack to compromise the legitimate network inference based methods for network monitoring, measurement or diagnosis. Real-world network datasets have been used to evaluate such threats in network systems with various settings. Experimental results confirm that, even for a single attacker that aims to disrupt the network inference by purposefully delaying or dropping data, the results of network inference can be significantly manipulated. The finding demonstrates that network inference under attacks can generate erroneous, misleading, and deceptive outputs. Countermeasures have also been created to detect the presence of such attacks.

The project has resulted in publications in major academic conferences and journals. The research results have been widely disseminated at conferences, workshops, and seminars, and have also been introduced in undergraduate and graduate classes, and related outreach events. 

 


Last Modified: 08/13/2018
Modified by: Zhuo Lu
